review: This has been a great app but, as with any consumer entered database, it‚Äôs only as good as the person entering the information.  If it seems too good to be true, scan and check for yourself!  Correct information when you find errors!!!  Let‚Äôs keep the integrity of this app worthy of its cause!
title: Check, Check and Triple Check
developerResponse:
{'id': 32419651, 'body': 'Data reliability is very important to us, and we do everything we can to ensure that the information is completely reliable.

The information submitted by users is, first of all, secured via an automatic management system within the app through image and text recognition.

After this stage, a double verification process of products added to the app takes place:

- Verification by Yuka staff: two people work full-time on managing the database, and they deal with checking contributions and correcting them where necessary.

- Verification by other users: Yuka users can correct an error directly in the app, or flag it to the team members for correction. Errors passed on to us are corrected within 24 hours.  

It should be noted that a certain number of product files cannot be edited by users. These are product files that have been verified by our team members, or whose information has been submitted by the relevant companies (this information corresponds to the information on the product labels, and therefore does not present any conflict of interest).

Finally, if a user enters incorrect data then that user is banned straight away, and can no longer use the app on his/her phone. Fortunately, this very rarely happens!


I hope this answers your question. 
', 'modified': '2022-10-06T08:51:24Z'}

title: NOT RELIABLE
developerResponse:
{'id': 37335708, 'body': "Hello, 
Yuka does not take into account the quantity of an ingredient for several reasons: The % is rarely indicated on the product some ingredients, such as endocrine disruptors, are problematic even in small quantities some ingredients, even if they are contained in small quantities, are present in many products, so that you're easily exposed to higher amounts. 

We also take a precautionary approach when evaluating, however you should certainly be able to access the descriptions and sources provided. This information is reviewed regularly by our in-house toxicologist to ensure we are up to date. 

 I hope this makes the evaluation clearer! Kind regards, Briana", 'modified': '2023-06-26T13:13:08Z'}

developerResponse:
{'id': 36287963, 'body': 'Hello,

The same analyses are used for all products, regardless of brand, price, or other. Furthermore, the analyses focus on the different components, not on product efficiency. 
For further information and what may have caused this reaction, I would encourage you to reach out to your preferred physician.

Our app was born from the intention to help consumers make more informed decisions, certainly not to "fear monger". We remain to this day 100% independent and do not accept any partnerships, sponsorships or other.

We apologize for any disappointment you experienced, however please refrain from spreading misinformation.

All of our information is available on our website.

Best, 
Briana', 'modified': '2023-05-02T15:42:57Z'}

title: Use of the app

review: Yuka uses sources that aren‚Äôt relevant to what the use of products are. For example they use a study with rats in it but humans aren‚Äôt rats and the ingredient is only bad if it‚Äôs ingested. However I forgot what ingredient it is. It‚Äôs only a convenient app if the sources are being used in the correct way. The ingredient cyclopentasiloxane is seen as bad in sunscreen aerosols and hair styling aerosols but the SCCS deems it as fine in certain products due to the concentration. Even if it is fine in a product, Yuka reviews it as bad due to it being bad in some cases.
title: Not correct information
developerResponse:
{'id': 37335286, 'body': "Hello, Yuka does not take into account the quantity of an ingredient for several reasons:

The % is rarely indicated on the product
some ingredients, such as endocrine disruptors, are problematic even in small quantities
some ingredients, even if they are contained in small quantities, are present in many products, so that you're easily exposed to higher amounts

I hope this makes the evaluation clearer!

Kind regards, Briana", 'modified': '2023-06-26T13:01:32Z'}

developerResponse:
{'id': 35017102, 'body': 'Hello Rosie,

Yuka is a free app. All users have access to the main features which include: scanning; recommendations, access to your scan-history, and a personalized summary.

We also have a Premium version, which is completely optional, that allows access to the following features:
Advanced search bar 
Offline mode
Personalized alerts when a product contains gluten, lactose, palm oil, etc.


Besides these features, the Premium version allows Yuka to remain financially independent which is very important to us üòä

I hope this helps clarify

My best,

Briana', 'modified': '2023-02-22T15:03:44Z'}

title: LOVE LOVE LOVE

review:
Was very helpful but then I noticed that they update things as they go, example: Celsius was ranked highly on Yuka, around 74/75 and didn‚Äôt had anything bad or harmful for someone who‚Äôs working out or looking some alternative for other energy drinks, one day just changed to 33 or so which is the same rate as Red Bull. Not just that, they also updated all my history search, so they probably don‚Äôt get sued by bunch of people for false information etc. 

Very very disappointing experience.
title: Yuka üëé
developerResponse:
{'id': 38717128, 'body': "Hello,

Celsius' grade went down as we updated the risk-level of Sucralose, an artificial sweetener which has recently been confirmed by several studies as severely affecting blood glucose levels and increases risk of cancer and cardiovascular disease.

We work with an in-house toxicologist and nutritionist and, as new studies are published and as compositions are updated, we update the entries so they have the most recent version of each product. This is why sometimes products may change.

Yuka is 100% independent and, having had our own long legal battles in France already, we stand by the truth and the analyses in place. No brand or manufacturer can pay to change their rating or appear in recommendations. 

I'm sorry this was disappointing to you, but products do tend to evolve and if new information comes to light we owe it to ours users to constantly update.

Kind regards, Briana", 'modified': '2023-09-04T15:51:23Z'}

review: I paid a $14 donation for the app but I still have to invite a friend in order to be able to see the lists of top products? First 10 minutes using it and already annoyed.
title: I can‚Äôt access the list of top products even after paying‚Ä¶
developerResponse:
{'id': 38273564, 'body': "Hello Tracii,
Thank you for your feedback and please accept our apologies for the disappointment this may have caused.

Please send us an email at: team@yuka.io so we can get this unblocked for you. 

We are in the starting blocks of our expansion in the USA and, with this new feature, we thought we might ask our valued user-base to help us spread the word to help Yuka become better known and grow in the United States.  Our goal is to make this tool available to as many people as possible, which is why the decision to unblock via sharing for all users was put in place at this time.

We do, however, understand that our Premium users may feel dismayed as you contribute to the project‚Äôs independence via your subscription. Please know we do not take this for granted and are grateful for your support.

I hope you'll enjoy this feature regardless and we hope you accept our apologies over this. ", 'modified': '2023-08-14T07:58:25Z'}

- I might be eating this as meal (my 260 calorie oatmeal says it has too many calories but it‚Äôs my entire breakfast so‚Ä¶)

{'id': 34720717, 'body': 'Hello! Thank you for your review! 

You should be able to change the language in your Settings :)

- If your phone doesn't have the last system update, you need to go to "Settings", "General", "Language and region" and choose the language that you would like to use Yuka in

We apologize for these errors.

Could you please write to us quickly at team@yuka.io to tell us what these products are? We will be able to correct them right away. Thank you very much for your help.

Data reliability is very important to us, and we do everything we can to ensure that the information is completely reliable.


The information submitted by users is, first of all, secured via an automatic management system within the app through image and text recognition.


After this stage, a double verification process of products added to the app takes place:


- Verification by Yuka staff: two people work full-time on managing the database, and they deal with checking contributions and correcting them where necessary.


- Verification by other users: Yuka users can correct an error directly in the app, or flag it to the team members for correction. Errors passed on to us are corrected within 24 hours.  

It should be noted that a certain number of product files cannot be edited by users. These are product files that have been verified by our team members, or whose information has been submitted by the relevant companies (this information corresponds to the information on the product labels, and therefore does not present any conflict of interest).


Finally, if a user enters incorrect data then that user is banned straight away, and can no longer use the app on his/her phone. Fortunately, this very rarely happens!


I hope this answers your question. 

Have a good day', 'modified': '2022-01-28T09:11:03Z'}

review: It‚Äôs an excellent app and I‚Äôm glad it doesn‚Äôt force you to subscribe to use the basic feature. But I wish it didn‚Äôt count more calories as a negative thing, it‚Äôs pretty silly since the whole point of eating food is to consume calories in order to live. Other than that I like it.

developerResponse: {'id': 24664638, 'body': "Hi! We're very happy you find the app useful, thanks a lot for the positive comment!\nAbout calories, they're one of 7 criteria used to evaluate the nutritional quality of a product. The others are: saturated fat, sugar, salt as negative points and protein, % of fruits and vegetables and fibers as positive points. So all in all the calories account for a very little part of the total evaluation of a product. I hope this helps you to better understand the rating method we're using. ", 'modified': '2021-08-23T11:21:24Z'}

developerResponse:
{'id': 30981512, 'body': 'Thanks very much, we are delighted that you like the app and that you find it useful :)

When you scan a product and it comes up as "unknown", you can add it directly using the app. To do this:

1) Select the product from your history then click the button "Fill in the information".
2) Follow the instructions in the app and take photos of the product information  requested.

If the button "Fill in the information" does not appear, this means that it is probably a product that Yuka cannot rate (alcohol, food supplement, etc.).

The product score will then be calculated automatically. The product is then saved in the database and can be accessed by other users.', 'modified': '2022-07-19T20:49:51Z'}

title: Good and bad
developerResponse:
{'id': 38447536, 'body': "Hello,
At Yuka, we understand how important the use of personal data is. For reasons of independence and for ethical reasons, Yuka does not sell or exploit any user's personal data.

If you wish to know more about our business model and how the app is financed, take a look here:
https://yuka.io/en/independence/
 
Signing up is obligatory for two reasons:

1. To enable a scan history to be attached to an account
2. To provide security for users' contributions. Yuka is a collaborative app to which anyone can contribute. It is therefore essential for us to use an account creation facility to allow us to secure the thousands of contributions we receive. By using such a system, we are able to ban users who provide incorrect information and, conversely, assign more rights to users that fully contribute to the process of providing high quality information.
", 'modified': '2023-08-22T07:24:03Z'}

Thank you for reaching out.

Indeed, this feature is no longer available. It has been replaced by a ranking of the "Top Products" scanned in Yuka. This was a highly requested feature and we wanted to keep the app simple and clean.

review:
Not up to date on some of the current healthy eating guidelines. I appreciate learning what chemicals are in a product, but don‚Äôt give products a bad rating because it has olive oil. That‚Äôs a FAR BETTER choice than something with canola oil, which gets high ratings.  We eat far to many foods that are processed or filled with 
pro inflammatory ingredients.
title: What guidelines?
developerResponse:
{'id': 34720610, 'body': 'Hello,

One of the main issues linked to consuming certain seed oils is their saturated fat content, which can sometimes be high. Yuka does take the amount of saturated fats into account in its product analyses: the higher the amount of saturated fats is in a product, the lower its grade will be.

Regarding Omega-6, which are part of the unsaturated fats group, you should certainly limit your consumption of these. The balance of our Omega-3 and Omega-6 intake is what will have the biggest effect on this: we should consume at most 5 times more Omega-6 than Omega-3.

I hope this helps clarify

Kind regards,
Briana', 'modified': '2023-02-07T08:57:53Z'}

review: Company may be bought buy bigger companies. My electrolyte of choice recommended by a nutritionist says it‚Äôs too caloric with 1 calorie while a Gatorade drink has 10 calories says it is all good for calories, same drinks my drink says it‚Äôs too salty at 55 mg while the same Gatorade drink is all good at 160 mg. Why are they not getting the same rating. I am so disappointed I really liked this app, now I don‚Äôt trust it anymore.
title: Not accurate
developerResponse:
{'id': 30981480, 'body': 'In order to answer you as well as possible, could you specify these products by sending us an email to team@yuka.io ? Thank you in advance for your help. 

According to our rating method, which is based on the Nutri-Score criteria, the rating scale for beverages (excluding milk) is stricter for calories and sugar than for solids.

This is because a liquid is immediately absorbed by the body and has a higher glycemic index. This is why liquid calories and sugars are penalised more severely.

I hope this answers your question.', 'modified': '2022-07-19T20:45:59Z'}

developerResponse:
{'id': 38447452, 'body': "Hello Alex,

Thank you for your feedback and please accept our apologies for the disappointment this may have caused.

The new app update will automatically unlock this feature for Premium users, as your support towards the project means everything to us. Please head over to the AppStore and manually update your app.

We are in the starting blocks of our expansion in the USA and, with this new feature, we thought we might ask our valued user-base to help us spread the word to help Yuka become better known and grow in the United States.  Our goal is to make this tool available to as many people as possible, which is why the decision to unblock via sharing for all users was put in place at this time.

I hope you'll enjoy this feature regardless and we hope you accept our apologies over this. ", 'modified': '2023-08-22T07:20:09Z'}

review:
This app is going to confuse people on what health really means. Stop scanning items that are clearly processed goods. Just buy actual Whole Foods that cannot be scanned. 
This app told me that my grass Fed butter was bad because of saturated fat. But then a cereal I had that literally had soybean oil was good for me??? Haha what a joke. Saturated fat is amazingly healthy. Our ancestors knew this and ate it daily. The chronic disease epidemic is from CEREALS and packaged goods. Not from butter‚Ä¶cmon do better.
title: Misinformation on saturated fats
developerResponse:
{'id': 38563521, 'body': 'Hello,

Each food product is rated according to three criteria:

The nutritional quality is attributed a possible 60% of the score. The calculation method is based on the recommendations of Professor Serge Hercberg within the framework of the French National Health Strategy proposed by the State and validated through the implementation of the Nutri-Score. This method takes into account the following nutritional criteria: calories, sugar, salt, saturated fats, protein, fiber, fruits and vegetables.

Additives represent 30% of the product score. We base this on numerous sources conducted to study the harmful effects of food additives.

Our framework for the analysis of additives is based on current scientific research. We take the following into account:


The scientific opinions of official bodies such as the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA), the French Agency for Food, Environmental and Occupational Health & Safety (ANSES), and the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC).
All of the independent scientific studies on the subject.


The organic composition represents 10% of the score. This is a bonus granted to products considered organic, ie those with an official national or international organic label. ﻿They avoid chemical pesticides which can pose a health risk.

For more information on different types of fats, their benefits and their concerns, you can check out the article on our blog: https://yuka.io/en/basics/lipids/  

Have a great day, Briana
', 'modified': '2023-08-28T08:38:40Z'}

review: I‚Äôve been into nutrition for years and I‚Äôve used many apps for tracking food, finding alternative foods to ones that aren‚Äôt as healthy. This app CLAIMS it will do that, however it doesn‚Äôt. It misleads and conflicts with other very reliable apps which are backed by doctors and nutritionists. I deleted Yuka after four days of use. Not only was it inaccurate, but many foods are missing.
title: Inaccurate, misleading and conflicting
developerResponse:
{'id': 24095626, 'body': 'Hello,

Each product is rated according to three criteria:

1 - The nutritional quality is attributed a possible 60% of the score.  The calculation method is based on the recommendations of Professor Serge Hercberg within the framework of the French National Health Strategy proposed by the State and validated through the implementation of the Nutri-Score.  This method takes into account the following nutritional criteria: calories, sugar, salt, saturated fats, protein, fiber, fruits and vegetables.

2 -Additives represent 30% of the product score.  We base this on numerous sources conducted to study the harmful effects of food additives.
Our framework for the analysis of additives is based on current scientific research.  We take the following into account:
- The scientific opinions of official bodies such as the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) , the French Agency for Food, Environmental and Occupational Health & Safety (ANSES), and the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC).
- All of the independent scientific studies on the subject.

3 - The organic composition represents 10% of the score. Products considered organic are those bearing the USDA label.

When you scan a product and it comes up as "unknown", you can add it directly using the app. To do this:

1) Select the product from your history then click the button "Fill in the information".
2) Follow the instructions in the app and take photos of the product information  requested.

If the button "Fill in the information" does not appear, this means that it is probably a product that Yuka cannot rate (alcohol, food supplement, etc.).

The product score will then be calculated automatically. The product is then saved in the database and can be accessed by other users.

I hope that answers your question.', 'modified': '2021-07-23T16:10:18Z'}

The ratings on here certainly aren‚Äôt accurate.

title: Beware of Fragrance
developerResponse:
{'id': 35757502, 'body': 'Hello,

Fragrance and Natural flavors are rated as "No risk" according to EU legislation, however we are reviewing the risk level for the US as legislation in place is not the same in Europe. 

Yuka is a 100% independent application funded through 3 sources of revenue:
The Premium version of the application. Learn more here !
Our book (only available in France, Italy and Germany)
A calendar of seasonal fruits and vegetables (sold in France and Spain only)

We refuse to partake in any form of partnership and we remain ad-free on our app for the same reason.
In the spirit of transparency, we have also made our Balance sheet public and it remains available on our website.

Thank you for your patience while we continue to develop the app!

Have a great day, Briana', 'modified': '2023-04-04T07:03:47Z'}

review:
The concept of the app is good, and I think it‚Äôs generally well built but the ratings cannot be trusted.

They will give certain ingredients a bad rating, but ignore the context it‚Äôs used.  For example, an ingredient in my shampoo is hazardous because it shouldn‚Äôt be used as a ‚Äúleave on‚Äù substance.  For shampooing it‚Äôs not leave on anyways

They also rate MSG as Hazardous?  Is this a joke?  Studies have countless debunked the myth of MSG being unhealthy. 

They also fail to rate seed oils as unhealthy compared less processed ones.  But that‚Äôs based on my own research, why trust me right?  Well why trust Yuka?   Either way it‚Äôs going to be incredibly biased, which is the challenge of making an app like this.
title: Misleading information
developerResponse:
{'id': 35017048, 'body': 'Hi Drew, Thank you for your feedback! 

Each product is evaluated according to three criteria:

The nutritional quality is attributed a possible 60% of the score (calories, sugar, salt, saturated fats, protein, fiber, fruits and vegetables).
Additives represent 30% of the product score. 
The organic composition represents 10% of the score.  

On our end the information we base ourselves on shows that one of the main issues linked to consuming certain seed oils is their saturated fat content, which can sometimes be high. Yuka does take the amount of saturated fats into account in its product analyses: the higher the amount of saturated fats is in a product, the lower its grade will be.

Regarding Omega-6, which are part of the unsaturated fats group, you should certainly limit your consumption of these. The balance of our Omega-3 and Omega-6 intake is what will have the biggest effect on this: we should consume at most 5 times more Omega-6 than Omega-3.

Thanks again and have a great day!

Briana ', 'modified': '2023-02-22T15:00:41Z'}

developerResponse:
{'id': 34841986, 'body': "Hello,

My apologies. 
When products come up with different ratings, this might be due to:
the fact that there are different versions of this product in circulation, with different compositions. Please note that for every product you scan, you can compare the ingredients' list on the product with the list you find in the product sheet, in order to see which is the right rating of the product you have.
There might also be that one of the two ingredient's lists is outdated. In order to be able to check if we have the most recent composition, we'd need to know which is the concerned product: the easiest option is to send us an up-to-date screenshot of the products concerned.

I hope this brings more clarity. Don't hesitate to send us the screenshots so we can provide you more information at: team@yuka.io

Warm regards, Briana", 'modified': '2023-02-13T15:57:56Z'}

review: You can not rank a product based on having an organic label. I know for a fact that organic products still get sprayed with chemical pesticides. Also, they typically have more pesticides sprayed on them versus conventional agriculture, therefore, organic requires even more work and is no better than conventional agriculture. Please do your homework first because you are misleading a lot of people.
title: Organic does not mean better
developerResponse:
{'id': 34176742, 'body': 'Thank you for your comment. The information we have available shows the label can only be applied if any prohibited substances (including fertilizers and pesticides) are not used in the three years prior to the harvest. Additionally, the Organic component of the grade only represents a 10% bonus, this does not define whether a product will be positively graded or not.
We will look into the information you have left here to see what improvements can be made in the app.

My best,

Briana', 'modified': '2023-01-09T13:32:37Z'}

title: No information on what is harmful
developerResponse:
{'id': 33169618, 'body': "Hello! 
Our apologies for this issue. This was due to a display-error that has since been corrected on our end. However, this has no impact on the product's grade. A new version of the app is now available and now correctly displays the full product information sheet.

Regarding recommendations, these are only available for poorly graded products and are selected through an algorithm according to availability, category and relevance. However, sometimes there are no recommendations available as they are also based on products available on the data base. Our apologies for this inconvenience.

I would encourage you to update the app and should you have any other questions please feel free to email us at: team@yuka.io 

Have a great day!", 'modified': '2022-11-15T09:09:52Z'}

review:
The information provided by this app is wrong and misleading. Please don‚Äôt use this app to make your decision based on. Use common sense and improve your knowledge in most aspect of life so you can live a healthy life.

Here is an example:
This is their scanner shows that have two different risk level profile:

Ingredients:
Cyclomethicone
Hazardous

Cyclopentasiloxane
Moderate risk

Now for average person, this is great.  But the fact is these are two names for same ingredient! Two different risk level. 
And this app is missing a serious information and knowledge about formulations, concentration level.
Stay away and don‚Äôt live in their false positive or false negative world.
title: This is a pure scam!

review:
I scanned products from Germany and the recommended alternatives are all from the US. That's incongruous.

Digging into the reasons for the ratings, I found inconsistencies in both the data and how the data map to the ratings.

Many products were simply not found. I was invited each time to provide information about the product, but there was too much input required at once. It wasn't possible to just upload an image and then add details later.

I tried to like it for a while but eventually gave up and uninstalled.
title: Recommended alternatives are for another country

title: Very helpful

review: I think this app is a sham when it comes to rating your own food. The recommendations show options that are supposed to be better but when I compare the two, it turns out that the product I‚Äôm eating is beyond better. Some examples are the protein plus shakes and the snyders pretzels; the recommendations are not at all better but rated higher. Makes sense.
title: Inconsistent ratings
developerResponse:
{'id': 26478780, 'body': 'Hello,

Yuka is a 100% independent application. This means that the recommendations are selected in a totally neutral and objective way: no brands pay or influence Yuka to appear in the recommendations.
 
The algorithm for the selection of alternatives takes into account:
 
- The product category (strawberry biscuits, goat's milk yoghurts, lip balms, solid soaps, etc.), in order to recommend a product as close as possible to the initial product.
- The product rating, in order to recommend only well-rated products, i.e. "good" or "excellent".
- The availability of the product, in order to recommend products that can be easily found anywhere.
 
It is also possible to filter these recommendations by retailer by selecting only the stores in which the consumer does their shopping. This filter only filters private-label brands and has no impact on major national brands.
 
I hope that's clarified it for you.', 'modified': '2021-11-25T15:51:34Z'}

review: I love this app with one exception: there needs to be a verified checkmark for products. I‚Äôve seen the same products uploaded by users with completely opposite ratings and then don‚Äôt know which is correct and then feel I can‚Äôt trust it.
title: This app has great potential

review: When I found Yuka I was so excited.. finally an app that rates food like Think Dirty rates self care & cleaning products. For the most part Yuka was pretty great until I noticed Yuka deemed a lot of products that contained seed oils such as canola oil as healthy. I‚Äôve now switched to the Trash Panda app & Bobby approved app to scan my products. They are aware of how unhealthy & inflammatory seed oils are & rate accordingly.
title: Yuka is .. Yucky
developerResponse:
{'id': 37335901, 'body': 'Hello, One of the main issues linked to consuming certain seed oils is their saturated fat content, which can sometimes be high. Yuka does take the amount of saturated fats into account in its product analyses: the higher the amount of saturated fats is in a product, the lower its grade will be.

Regarding Omega-6, which are part of the unsaturated fats group, you should certainly limit your consumption of these. The balance of our Omega-3 and Omega-6 intake is what will have the biggest effect on this: we should consume at most 5 times more Omega-6 than Omega-3.

This is the information we base ourselves on for ratings, I hope this helps clarify!

Briana', 'modified': '2023-06-26T13:17:22Z'}

review: This is horrible. My health teacher recommended this for ‚Äúbetter eating habits‚Äù and I scanned almost everything around the house. If I followed this my diet would consist of bread, peanut butter, salsa, pasta, prego sauce, eggs, and milk. The bad things for you are jam, cheese, (pizza rolls are better than cheese when it has cheese in it) ketchup, most sauces, pickles, orange juice, mayo, sour cream, lemon and lime juice, crackers, etc.
title: Horrible diet options
developerResponse:
{'id': 35659562, 'body': "Hello, 

Each food product is rated according to three criteria:

1. The nutritional quality is attributed a possible 60% of the score. The calculation method is based on the recommendations of Professor Serge Hercberg within the framework of the French National Health Strategy proposed by the State and validated through the implementation of the Nutri-Score. This method takes into account the following nutritional criteria: calories, sugar, salt, saturated fats, protein, fiber, fruits and vegetables.

2. Additives represent 30% of the product score. We base this on numerous sources conducted to study the harmful effects of food additives.

Our framework for the analysis of additives is based on current scientific research. We take the following into account:

The scientific opinions of official bodies such as the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA), the French Agency for Food, Environmental and Occupational Health & Safety (ANSES), and the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC).
All of the independent scientific studies on the subject.

3. The organic composition represents 10% of the score. This is a bonus granted to products considered organic, ie those with an official national or international organic label. ﻿They avoid chemical pesticides which can pose a health risk.

Don't hesitate to reach out to us at: team@yuka.io for further information.

Kind regards,
Briana", 'modified': '2023-03-29T15:23:41Z'}

{'id': 30622237, 'body': 'Hi,
We are so sorry for this experience.
Yuka analyses the intrinsic quality of products, regardless of the quantity consumed. This is why our rating system, based on government recommendations, is calculated based on 100 g of product. 
The purpose of the evaluation is to adjust the quantity consumed. The goal is not to ban products, but by being aware that a product is rated poorly, to adjust the quantity consumed.
We really hope that you kids feel better! 
', 'modified': '2022-06-29T13:06:18Z'}

developerResponse:
{'id': 33302781, 'body': 'Thank you for your feedback! Seed oils are not included in the product rating at this time. However, we will consider how they could be in the future.

Each product is evaluated according to three criteria:

The nutritional quality is attributed a possible 60% of the score (calories, sugar, salt, saturated fats, protein, fiber, fruits and vegetables).
Additives represent 30% of the product score. 
The organic composition represents 10% of the score.  

I hope this helps!

Have a good one,
Briana', 'modified': '2022-11-22T10:17:54Z'}

review: I think this is generally a good app, but be aware of embedded assumptions, such as fortification is considered a negative and results in a red dot. I also found it interesting that suggested options for an organic product were all non-organic. Which is very insightful, but perhaps of limited use of one is committed to organic foods.
title: Vitamins and minerals are considered a negative
developerResponse:
{'id': 24802889, 'body': 'Hi, 
Thanks for your feedback about our app.
To better understand how are recommendations are suggested, the algorithm for selecting alternatives takes into account:
- The product category (strawberry cookies, goat milk yogurt, lip balms, solid soaps etc.) in order to recommend a product that is as close as possible to the original product.
- Product rating in order to recommend only products with a good rating, i.e. "good" or "excellent".
- The availability of the product in order to recommend products that can be found easily everywhere.
If you need more details, don't hesitate to get back to us at team@yuka.io, we'll be happy to help. ', 'modified': '2021-08-30T12:25:34Z'}

review: This app reassures you from the false fears it creates. False fears because the poison is not in the substance itself by in the quantity (toxicology 101). Yet the mere presence of a substance suspected of having negative effects on the human body, appears in red. Imposture also because this app is clearly violating antitrust laws. Anyway, enjoy life while it last, and don‚Äôt get distracted by fearmongers.
title: Imposture
developerResponse:
{'id': 26670121, 'body': "Hello,
Yuka does not take into account the quantity of an ingredient for several reasons:
1) this % is almost never indicated by brands
2) some ingredients, especially endocrine disruptors, pose a problem even in small quantities
3) some ingredients, even if they are in small quantities, are present in many products, so that eventually you can quickly accumulate exposure to high amounts
If you have more questions, don't hesitate to contact us by email at team@yuka.io ", 'modified': '2021-12-06T13:23:11Z'}

title: Love the concept
developerResponse:
{'id': 28785780, 'body': 'Talc (hydrated magnesium silicate) is a mineral belonging to the same group as micas, and may contain aluminum silicate.

It is used for its absorbing power and because it makes the skin smoothy, particularly in make-up and baby products. Anyhow, its safety is frequently questioned. Talcum powder, when inhaled, is potentially irritating, even toxic, for the respiratory system. It is also better to avoid putting talk in contact with the eyes.

Studies have shown a correlation between the repeated use of talc and the development of cancer, particularly lung cancer (in the case of inhalation) and cancer of the ovaries (in the case of applications to the genitals). However, the carcinogenic nature of this substance has only been proven when it contains so-called asbestiform fibers (similar to those of asbestos). The IARC (International Agency for Research on Cancer) has classified talc not containing these asbestiform fibers in the category of substances whose carcinogenicity could not be proven (category 3).

However, precautions for its use are generally recommended. It is recommended to avoid inhalation by babies, as well as applications in the genital area.

I hope this answers your inquiry.', 'modified': '2022-03-25T16:40:13Z'}

review: I can‚Äôt trust this app when the same product is listed as excellent AND poor on different photos. Example of you search Estee Lauder the double wear foundation shows poor, however when you filter best rated it shows excellent which is untrue as estee has never been clean
title: Hard To Trust
developerResponse:
{'id': 29964945, 'body': 'Could you write to us at team@yuka.io? We will be able to check this product. Thank you very much for your help.

Data reliability is very important to us, and we do everything we can to ensure that the information is completely reliable.

The information submitted by users is, first of all, secured via an automatic management system within the app through image and text recognition.

After this stage, a double verification process of products added to the app takes place:

- Verification by Yuka staff: two people work full-time on managing the database, and they deal with checking contributions and correcting them where necessary.

- Verification by other users: Yuka users can correct an error directly in the app, or flag it to the team members for correction. Errors passed on to us are corrected within 24 hours.  

It should be noted that a certain number of product files cannot be edited by users. These are product files that have been verified by our team members, or whose information has been submitted by the relevant companies (this information corresponds to the information on the product labels, and therefore does not present any conflict of interest).

Finally, if a user enters incorrect data then that user is banned straight away, and can no longer use the app on his/her phone. Fortunately, this very rarely happens!

I hope this answers your question. ', 'modified': '2022-05-25T15:16:06Z'}

review:
I love love love this app!!! Knowing what has healthy or not so healthy ingredients in my store bought food, makes our healthy eating live style a piece of cake! Thank thank for inventing this app üôèüôåüôåüòÉ

review: It thinks saturated fat is bad. I don‚Äôt understand how any thinking person can believe that after reading any modern research on the subject. This app gives bad advice. It also just says food is bad if it‚Äôs high calorie. Not everyone is trying to lose weight. For me more calories is a good thing.
title: Outdated advice
developerResponse:
{'id': 35017057, 'body': 'Hi, Thank you for your feedback!
Each food product is rated according to three criteria:

1. The nutritional quality is attributed a possible 60% of the score. The calculation method is based on the recommendations of Professor Serge Hercberg within the framework of the French National Health Strategy proposed by the State and validated through the implementation of the Nutri-Score. This method takes into account the following nutritional criteria: calories, sugar, salt, saturated fats, protein, fiber, fruits and vegetables.

2. Additives represent 30% of the product score. We base this on numerous sources conducted to study the harmful effects of food additives.

Our framework for the analysis of additives is based on current scientific research. We take the following into account:

The scientific opinions of official bodies such as the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA), the French Agency for Food, Environmental and Occupational Health & Safety (ANSES), and the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC).
All of the independent scientific studies on the subject.


3. The organic composition represents 10% of the score. This is a bonus granted to products considered organic, ie those with an official national or international organic label. ﻿They avoid chemical pesticides which can pose a health risk.

Thanks again and have a great day,

Briana', 'modified': '2023-02-22T15:01:47Z'}

title: Positive criticism

review:
This is an amazing app. It really is! I have learned so much about the products I use daily and will start making some changes, since I learned the ones I was able to find are absolutely horrible for me. From food to cosmetic products!! I Love that you can pick how much you are able to pay for the yearly membership! I do wish there was links for the recommended alternatives of where you can buy them. But I realize that would most likely interfere with the whole independent recommendations aspect of it. 
My only complaint is, once I paid for the membership and started looking up products, I noticed there are mostly French and German food products. From places like Lidl and Aldi. I assume the creator is most likely French or German, but here in the states, not a lot of places have Aldi or Lidl. I WISH where I live in Colorado, we did. I miss those stores from being born and raised for 18 years in Germany. But most of my food products are from Walmart, Safeway and King Soopers. I haven‚Äôt found any store brands from either of those places, so most of my grocery purchases I wasn‚Äôt able to look up and learn about. Also a lot of the recommendations I‚Äôm not able to find in stores because they are not in said grocery stores where I live, but other stores like Aldi and Lidl. I hope one day the more generic store brands will be added, that would make me use the app on every single item! It would be awesome if there was a place to suggest products to the developer, so they can be added. But every other aspect of this app is amazing. I‚Äôm so grateful my husband showed me and I have recommended it to everyone from family to friends! Don‚Äôt let my store brand item critique persuade you to not get the app, this app is AMAZING. I hope they will continue to expand the selection because it has already made a big difference in my overall health, with recommendations of better products and educating me on ingredients. I‚Äôll keep looking up the items I can‚Äôt find in the hopes they will show up one day!
title: Great app!! But‚Ä¶

review: Recommend it for all
title: Great app! Stop putting poison in your body

review: Great and often used app. Love it. If it would list the ingredients of the food it would be AWESOME!
title: Great app, could be awesome with ‚Ä¶

review:
I freaking love this app! It has turned shopping for me into something that is full of anxiety and uncertainty into an enjoyable experience where I can be sure I trust the products I am buying and using. There are so many products that look ‚Äúorganic‚Äù and ‚Äúhealthy‚Äù for people but when I would go to read the ingredients it‚Äôs like‚Ä¶ ‚Äúhow do I even pronounce that word? What even is that? I don‚Äôt know‚Äù and would blindly be buying things or left looking up each ingredient in the isle on my phone and being confused and wasting so much time with my partner getting frustrated at how much time I‚Äôm taking up in the store. 

With this app you can scan items bar codes and it will list out the ingredients and why they might be bad or good. What they‚Äôre commonly used for and the risk factors. I absolutely love scanning items and being able to see what is good and what is so so bad. 

The only downside to this app is that it is disappointing to scan a product and see that it‚Äôs so bad for you but it makes me feel so good to know I know what I‚Äôm putting into and on my body. The best part of the app is that it‚Äôs turned shopping into a little game where I have my phone out and can scan everything and not waste any time worrying about whether or not I‚Äôm making the right choice. I‚Äôm happy and healthy and my partner is a lot happier with the amount of time we spend in the store. :) I look forward to using this app when I can and the more I use it, the more I know which products I can trust and which I can‚Äôt. :)
title: Life changing!!

review: this app has my whole heart i love it so much it‚Äôs rly opened my eyes on what products i‚Äôm using it‚Äôs the best app
title: YUKAA <3333

review: I absolutely love this app. It has been a game changer in helping me improve my health. Thank you!
title: Love love!

review: They want you to create an account to collect your data, for what to give you some data from their database? I‚Äôm sure there are other apps and sites that do the same without a sign up process.
title: This app looks great too bad it‚Äôs not
developerResponse:
{'id': 30668108, 'body': "Personal data is a matter we take very seriously.
For reasons of both ethics and independence, we neither sell nor make use of your personal data.
 
Membership is obligatory for two reasons:
 
1) to enable a scan history to be attached to an account
2) to provide security for users' contributions. Yuka is a collaborative app to which anyone can contribute. It is therefore essential for us to use an account creation facility to allow us to secure the thousands of contributions we receive. By using such a system, we are able to ban users who provide incorrect information and, conversely, assign more rights to users that fully contribute to the process of providing high quality information.
 
I hope this answers your concerns.", 'modified': '2022-07-01T15:30:49Z'}

review: I thought this one could be a good right hand when shopping. It doesn‚Äôt considerate vegetable oils or difference between added sugar and natural sugars. foreaxbale it told me sweet potato fries baked in avodavdo oil was unhealthy and suggested tugalar potato chips cooked in vegetable oils. That makes zero sense. Deleted it after the first 5 foods.
title: Not great at all
developerResponse:
{'id': 37884090, 'body': "Hello, 

One of the main issues linked to consuming certain seed oils is their saturated fat content, which Yuka does take into account in its product analyses: the higher the amount of saturated fats is in a product, the lower its grade will be.

For more details on Saturated fats, check out the article on our blog! 

Regarding sugars and added sugars, we are based in France and, while we continue to develop the app, sugars and added sugars are not differentiated on packaging a lot of the time and we have no access to the information.

We'll keep these in mind for future improvements of the app!

Have a great day, Briana", 'modified': '2023-07-25T07:32:44Z'}

review: The idea is great but a lot of the information entered is incorrect and there are many duplicate products.  All products should be independently verified (if entered by user) and the database needs to be purged of dups
title: Incorrect and duplicates
developerResponse:
{'id': 23256560, 'body': "Hi,

Thanks for your feedback.

It often happens that you see duplicate products because the brand did change the composition, and uses a new barcode for the new formula. In this case, we have two different products with two different scores due to these composition changes.

In the other hand, data reliability is very important to us, and we do everything we can to ensure that the information is completely reliable.

The information submitted by users is, first of all, secured via an automatic management system within the app through image and text recognition.

If you have a question about a product in particular, feel free to contact us at team@yuka.io :-) We'll be happy to help. ", 'modified': '2021-06-08T07:07:39Z'}

review: App has multiple entries for same product and gives them different ratings. WTH. Same product rated as bad and good. App data seems to be full of incorrect information.
title: Wrong product info
developerResponse: {'id': 34125606, 'body': "Hello Nicki. Thank you for your alert. It can indeed happen sometimes. However, we usually have two different ingredient lists for these products, which explains the difference in their ratings. However, it also is possible that the composition has changed. If the brand changed some of the ingredients but that both of the product's versions are still on the market, we have to keep them both in the app as well. Could you email us at team@yuka.io so that we can check some of the products you have seen ? Thank you in advance. Valentin.\nThank you very much in advance.", 'modified': '2023-01-06T07:48:20Z'}

review: I‚Äôve been at this clean lifestyle for 12 years now and knowing specific products are clean and seeing them labeled as ‚Äúpoor‚Äù on this app is laughable.  Who‚Äôs in charge of uploading products and then rating them?
title: Not worth it
developerResponse:
{'id': 31193242, 'body': 'Each product is rated according to three criteria:

1 - The nutritional quality is attributed a possible 60% of the score.  The calculation method is based on the recommendations of Professor Serge Hercberg within the framework of the French National Health Strategy proposed by the State and validated through the implementation of the Nutri-Score.  This method takes into account the following nutritional criteria: calories, sugar, salt, saturated fats, protein, fiber, fruits and vegetables.

2 -Additives represent 30% of the product score.  We base this on numerous sources conducted to study the harmful effects of food additives.
Our framework for the analysis of additives is based on current scientific research.  We take the following into account:
- The scientific opinions of official bodies such as the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) , the French Agency for Food, Environmental and Occupational Health & Safety (ANSES), and the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC).
- All of the independent scientific studies on the subject.

3 - The organic composition represents 10% of the score. Products considered organic are those bearing the French organic label (AB) and/or the European organic label (Euro Leaf).', 'modified': '2022-07-31T18:53:44Z'}
